Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Situation2: Medical advice suggests this may be their final opportunity to travel long distances.
Story:
The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as Mr. Rahman’s voice rose, sharp with suspicion. “How do I know this isn’t a scam? I’ve been with your company for years!” My script was ready, but my mind wandered. I was supposed to reassure him, answer every question, and keep him on the line. My supervisor expected me to close the deal, no matter how tough the call. But my heart was somewhere else—my doctor’s words echoing: “If you want to perform Hajj, this year is your best chance. Your health may not allow it again.” 

I felt the weight of my faith, the longing to fulfill a lifelong dream, and the pressure of my job, all colliding. Mr. Rahman’s frustration grew, and I knew I should focus, but my thoughts kept drifting to Mecca, to the sacred rituals I might never experience. The company needed me here, handling objections, but my soul was being pulled thousands of miles away. My hands trembled as I tried to answer Mr. Rahman, torn between duty to my work and the call of my faith, unsure which voice to follow.
